Hajiseyedjavadi O. Baase W.A. Matthews B.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 259: 542-559Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). Increased stability could translate into enhanced resistance to enzymatic proteolysis or reduce the requirement of refrigeration for storage by improving protein stability at ambient temperatures. Replacement of helical glycine residues with alanine, an amino acid with a much higher α-helical propensity, potentially provides a relatively simple means of increasing protein stability. The stabilization associated with such glycine to alanine substitutions can be attributed, in part, to the unfavorable entropic cost of constraining the glycine backbone into a helical conformation, relative to alanine. The net effect on protein stability of any amino acid change represents a balance between energetically favorable contributions, for example intrinsic α-helical propensity, and energetically unfavorable interactions, such as steric conflicts. The small increase in sidechain bulk involved in substituting the methyl group of alanine for the hydrogen of glycine helps to minimize the potential for introducing steric conflicts. We sought to improve the helical propensity of residues within the 4-helix bundle region of G-CSF by systematically replacing the 7 helical glycine residues with alanines. By generating and evaluating single point mutants, we were able to establish the effects of each change and then group them based on whether they were stabilizing or destabilizing relative to wild-type G-CSF. Alanine replacements at positions 73, 81, and 87 resulted in either a smaller increase or even a decrease in stability and for this reason were not utilized in later redesigns. The smaller increase in stability associated with G-CSF(G73A) can be explained in part by its localization at the N terminus of helix-B, adjacent to the disulfide bridging Cys-64 and Cys-74. The destabilizing effects of Gly/Ala replacements at positions 81 and 87 may be attributable to the close proximity of the AB and CD loops along much of helix-B. They could partially occlude residues on the surface of helix-B, and thus the methyl sidechain of alanine may introduce steric clashes. Additionally, the helix unwinds slightly in the turn containing position 81 allowing Leu-82 to pack into the core of the 4-helix bundle. Alanine replacement could interfere with this unwinding. Replacing glycine residues with alanine at positions 26, 28, 149, and 150 were found to result in the greatest increases in stability, and therefore, were used as the basis for future generations of mutants. Presumably this increased stabilization results from fewer deleterious interactions associated with the substituted alanine residue. Two successive reengineering cycles, combining favorable mutations, resulted in four versions of G-CSF with significant stability enhancements over the wild-type protein, G-CSF(G26A/G28A), G-CSF(G149A/G150A), G-CSF(G26A/G149A/G150A) and G-CSF(G28A/G149A/G150A). These mutants provide an opportunity to explore the correlation between the factors contributing to thermodynamic stability and those influencing pharmacokinetic properties. They also allow us to begin considering how protein stability may directly affect receptor-binding kinetics and thus biological activity. Variants of G-CSF and other cytokines with substantially enhanced stabilities have additional practical application potential. Many cell lines that are used in the laboratory and maintained in tissue culture are dependent on exogenously added cytokines for their survival and proliferation. The increased stability of the reengineered G-CSF variants described here could translate into extended effective lifetimes in tissue culture, thus reducing the amount and frequency of the cytokine supplement that is required. In addition, reengineered variants of G-CSF may also have potential therapeutic applications with immunosuppressed patients, where G-CSF is used to expedite the recovery of neutrophil counts that have been depleted as a result of chemotherapy. The dramatic improvements in the stability of G-CSF arising from double and triple Gly/Ala substitutions demonstrate the importance of intrinsic α-helix propensities to overall protein stability. These gains in stability were achieved without compromising the biological activity of G-CSF. Similar approaches can be used to rationally manipulate the physicochemical properties of other long chain cytokines, to optimize their preparation, efficacy, and storage properties. We thank Dr. John Reidhaar-Olson (Affymax Corporation) for fruitful conversations and for generously providing the pBAD-G4 plasmid. We are grateful to Dr. Tasuku Honjo (Kyoto University, Japan) for supplying the murine myeloid LGM-1 cells. We would also like to thank members of the Regan laboratory for invaluable contributions in preparing this paper.

Abstract Serpin family protein proteinase inhibitors trap proteinases at the acyl-intermediate stage of cleavage of the serpin as a proteinase substrate by undergoing a dramatic conformational change, which is thought to distort the proteinase active site and slow deacylation. To investigate the extent to which proteinase catalytic function is defective in the serpin-proteinase complex, we compared the pH dependence of dissociation of several serpin-proteinase acyl-complexes with that of normal guanidinobenzoyl-proteinase acyl-intermediate complexes. Whereas the apparent rate constant for dissociation of guanidinobenzoyl-proteinase complexes (k diss, app) showed a pH dependence characteristic of His-57 catalysis of complex deacylation, the pH dependence of k diss, app for the serpin-proteinase complexes showed no evidence for His-57 involvement in complex deacylation and was instead characteristic of a hydroxide-mediated deacylation similar to that observed for the hydrolysis of tosylarginine methyl ester. Hydroxylamine enhanced the rate of serpin-proteinase complex dissociation but with a rate constant for nucleophilic attack on the acyl bond several orders of magnitude slower than that of hydroxide, implying limited accessibility of the acyl bond in the complex. The addition of 10–100 mmCa2+ ions stimulated up to 80-fold the dissociation rate constant of several serpin-trypsin complexes in a saturable manner at neutral pH and altered the pH dependence to a pattern characteristic of His-57-catalyzed complex deacylation. These results support a mechanism of kinetic stabilization of serpin-proteinase complexes wherein the complex is trapped as an acyl-intermediate by a serpin conformational change-induced inactivation of the proteinase catalytic function, but suggest that the inactive proteinase conformation in the complex is in equilibrium with an active proteinase conformation that can be stabilized by the preferential binding of an allosteric ligand such as Ca2+.

To characterize the substrate specificity of the putative RNA:pseudouridine (Ψ)-synthase encoded by theSaccharomyces cerevisiae open reading frame (ORF) YGR169c, the corresponding gene was deleted in yeast, and the consequences of the deletion on tRNA and small nuclear RNA modification were tested. The resulting ΔYGR169c strain showed no detectable growth phenotype, and the only difference in Ψ formation in stable cellular RNAs was the absence of Ψ at position 31 in cytoplasmic and mitochondrial tRNAs. Complementation of the ΔYGR169c strain by a plasmid bearing the wild-type YGR169c ORF restored Ψ31formation in tRNA, whereas a point mutation of the enzyme active site (Asp168→Ala) abolished tRNA:Ψ31-synthase activity. Moreover, recombinant His6-tagged Ygr169 protein produced in Escherichia coli was capable of forming Ψ31 in vitro using tRNAs extracted from the ΔYGR169c yeast cells as substrates. These results demonstrate that the protein encoded by the S. cerevisiae ORF YGR169c is the Ψ-synthase responsible for modification of cytoplasmic and mitochondrial tRNAs at position 31. Because this is the sixth RNA:Ψ-synthase characterized thus far in yeast, we propose to rename the corresponding genePUS6 and the expressed protein Pus6p. Finally, the cellular localization of the green fluorescent protein-tagged Pus6p was studied by functional tests and direct fluorescence microscopy. Cellular organelles, such as the Golgi apparatus and the endoplasmic reticulum, adopt characteristic structures depending on their function. While the tubular shapes of these structures result from complex protein-lipid interactions that are not fully understood, some fundamental machinery must be required. We show here that a de novo-designed 18-mer amphipathic α-helical peptide, Hel 13-5, transforms spherical liposomes made from a Golgi-specific phospholipid mixture into nanotubules on the scale of and resembling the shape of the nanotubules that form the Golgi apparatus. Furthermore, we show that that the size and the shape of such nanotubules depend on lipid composition and peptide properties such as length and the ratio of hydrophobic to hydrophilic amino acids. Although the question of precisely how nature engineers organellar membranes remains unknown, our simple novel system provides a basic set of tools to begin addressing this question. For example, extensive membrane nanotubules, typically 50–70 nm in diameter and up to several µm in length, have been observed to form the Golgi complex, the trans Golgi network, and the connections between the Golgi stacks. The morphological engineering of these membranes involve complex interactions between proteins and lipids that are not yet understood (3Weidman P. Roth R. Heuser J. Cell. 1993; 75: 123-133Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 4Presley J.F. Smith C. Hirschberg K. Miller C. Cole N.B. Zaal K.J. Lippincott-Schwartz J. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1998; 9: 1617-1626Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). However, there must be some fundamental machinery required to form such structures. We recently described the properties of a de novo-designed 18-mer peptide, Hel 13-5 (5Kiyota T. Lee S. Sugihara G. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 13196-13204Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar, 6Kitamura A. Kiyota T. Tomohiro M. Umeda A. Lee S. Inoue T. Sugihara G. Biophys. J. 1999; 76: 1457-1468Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). This peptide can adopt an ideal α-helix having a 240° hydrophobic sector region (Fig.1A). It forms a self-association state in buffer solution by adopting this amphipathic structure (70% α-helical structure by CD), and it binds to model- and biomembranes with high affinity. In the present study, we show that Hel 13-5 induces nanotubular structures, not only for PC liposomes, but also for various naturally occurring phospholipids. Most importantly, we demonstrate that Hel 13-5 transforms spherical liposomes made from a Golgi-specific phospholipid mixture into nanotubules on the scale of, and resembling the shape of, the nanotubules of the Golgi apparatus. Peptide was synthesized by the Fmoc1 strategy based on the solid phase technique starting from Fmoc-PAL-PEG resin using a PerSeptive 9050 automatic peptide synthesizer described previously (5Kiyota T. Lee S. Sugihara G. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 13196-13204Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). The stock solutions of Hel peptides were prepared as follows: the powders were damped with a small amount of 30% acidic acid and then diluted in buffer (5 mm Tes/100 mm NaCl, pH 7.4). The peptide concentrations in the buffer solution were determined from the UV absorbance of Trp at 280 nm (ε = 5500). A lipid solution in chloroform was filmed in a round bottom flask by drying in a stream of N2gas. The lipid film was hydrated with the Tes buffer by vortexing. The turbid liposome solution obtained was then diluted to a concentration of about 100 µm with the same buffer. The peptide solutions were then added to the solution to attain a given molar ratio of the peptide to lipid and then incubated at 25 °C. The absorbance of the sample solution was recorded at 400 nm using a JASCO spectrometer (Tokyo, Japan) after vigorous vortexing. The viscosities of Hel 13-5 and egg PC liposome solutions were obtained by a rotary type viscosity meter DV-II with a spindle type s40 (Brookfield EnG Labs Inc.). The sample solution was placed between the sample cup and the spindle after incubation at 25 °C for 24 h. The rotation velocity of the spindle was 50 rpm. The relative viscosity (η) was calculated using the following equation η = ηΘ / η0where ηI and η0 are the viscosities of liposome solutions in the presence and absence of peptide, respectively. Unilamellar liposomes with a controlled size distribution of about 80∼90 nm in diameter were prepared by the extrusion method (7Mayer L.D. Hope M.J. Cullis P.R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1986; 856: 161-168Crossref Scopus (1565) Google Scholar). The liposomes formed by ultrasonic irradiation in the cuphorn of a Branson model 185 sonifier at room temperature were extruded through two stacked polycarbonate filters with a 100- and 200-nm pore size by applying nitrogen pressure and collected and re-extruded into an Extruder (Lipex Biomembranes Inc., Vancouver, Canada). The liposome solution (0.2 mm, 1 ml) was then added to the peptide solution (1 ml) at the appropriate concentrations at 25 °C. A NICOMP Submicron Particle Sizer, Model 370, with an argon ion laser (λ = 488 nm) of 75 milliwatt maximum power was used to measure liposome size (6Kitamura A. Kiyota T. Tomohiro M. Umeda A. Lee S. Inoue T. Sugihara G. Biophys. J. 1999; 76: 1457-1468Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). CD spectra were obtained using a JASCO J-600 spectrometer using a quartz cell with 1-mm path length. The peptide solutions were prepared at concentrations of 40∼50 µm in the presence and absence of egg PC liposomes. Lipids were stored at 1 mm concentration. For whole-amount observation, liposomes prepared in 5 mm Tes buffer (pH 7.4) containing 100 mm NaCl and 1 mm EDTA. The peptide concentration was 100 µm (lipid/peptide = 5). All the peptides were incubated for about 24 h with liposomes before the negative staining. The sample solutions were placed on carbon-coated grids and stained with 0.5% phosphotungstic acid adjusted to pH 7.4. For thin sectioning, the incubation mixture was fixed in a suspension of 2% glutaraldehyde in Tes buffer, pelleted in an Eppendorf centrifuge, and postfixed in OsO4. The precipitate was mixed with 3% agar solution, cut in 1 cm3 cubes, dehydrated by ethanol and propylene oxide, embedded in Epon 815, and sectioned. When Hel 13-5 was added to PC liposomes, the liposomes were transformed from spherical structures into twisted ribbon-like fibrils ∼25–50 nm in diameter and more than a few µm in length as determined by TEM (Fig.1, B and C). We confirmed that Hel 13-5 induces twisted helical-shaped fibrils in egg PC liposomes using atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Fig. 1, Dand E). Under low magnification, TEM revealed a great many circular- and sheath-like nanotubular structures (Fig. 1F). Under high magnification, there were many unilamellar shapes including double-lamellar structures. The tubules were about 40–50 nm in diameter and 5 nm in thickness for unilamellar, and 10 nm in thickness for double-lamellar layers (Fig. 1G). Relative viscosity (η) measurements of the peptide-lipid solution demonstrated that the fibrils begin to form at a ratio of peptide to lipid (P/L) of about 1:10 as measured by the onset of a change in viscosity (Fig.1H). Because Hel 13-5 reshaped membranes in a simple system composed only of egg PC liposomes, it is logical to ask whether or not Hel 13-5 could also demonstrate this ability in a more complex and realistic biomembrane system, such as the liposomes formed from an organelle-specific mixture of phospholipids. We considered the effect of Hel 13-5 on the spherical liposomes formed from a Golgi-specific phospholipid mixture (PC/PE/PS/PI/SM/Ch = 50:16:5:6:7:17). We found that Hel 13-5 did indeed alter the morphology of the spherical liposomes made from a Golgi-specific phospholipid mixture. However, it was a surprise to find that Hel 13-5 induced the formation of nanotubules on the scale of, and with the shapes characteristic of, the nanotubules forming the Golgi apparatus (Fig.2A). These nanotubules (large arrow) had diameters of ∼40–50 nm and lengths of ∼400 nm. They were formed from larger tubules with lengths of ∼600 nm that had both ends pinched off into twisted tubules with extremely small diameters of ∼2–3 nm (small arrows). These 400 nm nanotubules bore a remarkable morphological resemblance to the nanotubules of the Golgi apparatus (8Alberts B. Bray B. Lewis J. Raff M. Roberts K. Watson J.D. Molecular Biology of The Cell. 3rd Ed. Garland Publishing, New York and London1994: 601-602Google Scholar) and were absolutely distinct from the fibrils formed by the interaction of Hel 13-5 and the egg PC phospholipid liposomes (Fig. 1, B–E). Although Hel 13-5 formed fibrils with neutral (PC) bilayers, we previously found that it formed fused vesicles in acidic liposomes (PC/PG = 3:1) (6Kitamura A. Kiyota T. Tomohiro M. Umeda A. Lee S. Inoue T. Sugihara G. Biophys. J. 1999; 76: 1457-1468Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Thus, fibril formation depends on the lipid species. To investigate in greater detail the dependence of nanotubule formation on lipid composition, we studied the interaction between Hel 13-5 and various neutral and acidic lipid species by means of electron microscopy, turbidity, and dynamic light scattering (TableI). Electron micrographs taken 24 h after the addition of Hel 13-5 to several liposome systems are shown in Fig. 2, B–F. We found that the resulting morphology was indeed dependent on the lipid mixture. Hel 13-5 incubated with the PC/PE/SM (5:3:2) mixture induced fibril formation containing resinoid, branched tree structures (Fig. 2B). Hel 13-5 incubated with pure SM liposomes induced a mixture of ring-like structures and fibrils with diameters of ∼25 nm and lengths of ∼500 nm (Fig.2C). These fibrils were much shorter than those created by Hel 13-5 with pure neutral (PC) liposomes. Hel 13-5 incubated with a neutral/acidic liposome mixture PC/PG (3/1) at a high peptide/lipid ratio (3:1), also induced the formation of twisted tubular fibers with lengths greater than a few µm and with diameters of ∼25 nm (Fig.2D). With the mixture PC/PE/Ch (5:3:2), Hel 13-5 created curved fibril structures that exhibited surface bumps, mixed with large ring structures (Fig. 2E). The interaction of Hel 13-5 with a lipid mixture based on lung surfactant lipids, DPPC/PC/PG/PE (4:4:1:1) lead to the creation of a mixture of tubular and doughnut-type structures (Fig. 2F). Taken as a whole, the above data imply that Hel 13-5 induces a diverse array of lipid-specific nanotubular structures. Interestingly, a system composed of Hel 13-5 and a lipid mixture based on myelin lipids, Ch/PC/PE/PS/SM/cerebroside (43:9:12:5:10:21), did not form any fibril structures, thus demonstrating that tubule formation was not a universal phenomenon for Hel 13-5 (data not shown).Table IList of the lipid systems studiedLipid typeLipid componentsNeutral lipidsEgg PC, SM, Egg PC/egg PE (1:1)1-aThe numbers in parentheses are molar ratio of lipids., PC/PE/SM (5:3:2)PC/PE/Ch (5:3:2)Acidic lipidsPC/PG (3:1), PC/PS (3:1)Lung surfactant lipidsDPPC/PC/PG/PE (4/4/1/1)Golgi lipidsPC/PE/PS/PI/SM/Ch (50/10/5/6/7/17)Myelin lipidsCh/PE/SM/PS/SM/cerebroside (43/9/12/5/10/21)1-a The numbers in parentheses are molar ratio of lipids. Thus, structures found this way cannot completely reflect the actual structures in solution, and these structures are the ones of interest. We previously reported that the formation of fibril structures by lipid-peptide complexes in solution can often be detected by the combination of a decrease in turbidity of neutral lipid (egg-PC) suspensions and an increase in mean diameter of the peptide-lipid complex, as measured by dynamic light scattering (6Kitamura A. Kiyota T. Tomohiro M. Umeda A. Lee S. Inoue T. Sugihara G. Biophys. J. 1999; 76: 1457-1468Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Based on this concept, mixed systems of Hel 13-5 with other lipids such as PE, SM, PS, PG, and Ch were examined in solution for the formation of nanotubular/fibril structures (Fig.3). The addition of Hel 13-5 to the PC/PE-mixed liposomes at ratio of 1:1 led to a decrease in turbidity of lipid suspension rapidly within 1 h at the low peptide concentrations (Fig. 3A). The solution-clearing ability of Hel 13-5 on this phospholipid mixture was much stronger than that of the Hel 13-5/PC pure liposome mixture. Addition of other neutral lipids such as SM or Ch to PC/PE liposomes (PC/PE/SM or PC/PE/Ch = 5:3:2) exhibited no significant difference in clearing ability as compared with those of PC/PE liposomes. In the case of SM alone, the turbidity of lipid suspension was slightly decreased with increasing concentration of Hel 13-5 (Fig.3A). A mixture PC/PE/Ch (5:3:2) and a mixture based on the lung surfactant lipids, DPPC/PC/PG/PE (4:4:1:1), did not show much of a decrease in liposome-turbidity with increasing concentration of Hel 13-5 (Fig. 3A). In general, solution turbidities either decreased or remained constant. The time-dependent changes in liposome size after the addition of the Hel 13-5 (20 µm) to several liposome solutions (100 µm) were then considered (Fig.3B). The sizes of PC liposomes and PC/PE-, PC/PE/SM-, and PC/PE/Ch-mixed liposomes increased with time in similar ways. On the other hand, the size of pure SM liposomes treated with Hel 13-5 increased more gradually than the other systems. These results are in agreement with the electron microscopy that showed that SM formed smaller size fibers. Overall, the turbidity and liposome size data were consistent with the electron microscopy data in the determination of fibril/nanotubule formation. We investigated the relationship between the peptide sequence and the fibril structure formation. In this regard, we designed and synthesized a set of Hel 13-5-related peptides as shown in Table II. All the peptides we designed adopted an amphipathic α-helix structure with a 240° hydrophobic sector. The peptides Hel 17-7 and Hel 8-4 were made to study the effect of chain length. Hel 13-5V, Hel 13-5Nle, and L9GHel 13-5 were created to look at the role of hydrophobicity. Hel 13-5R and E3Hel 13-5 were synthesized to consider the role of hydrophilicity. In addition, we considered KL4W, a transmembrane helical peptide evaluated as a therapeutic surfactant for respiratory distress syndrome (9Cochrane C.G. Revax S.D. Science. 1991; 254: 566-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). For simplicity, we began our evaluation of the peptides in an egg PC system. CD studies showed that Hels 13-5, 17-7, L9GHel 13-5, 13-5R and KL4W adopted α-helical structure, whereas Hels 8-4 and 13-5V took on β-strand structures in PC liposomes. To determine the resulting structure of the lipid-peptide interaction, the mean diameter and change of turbidity of liposomes after the incubation of peptides with the liposomes at 25 °C were measured. The mean diameter increased drastically for Hels 13-5R and L9GHel 13-5, and gradually for Hel 13-5 Nle as shown in Fig. 4B. These results were consistent with electron micrographs that showed the former peptides formed long fibers and the latter one formed short ones (data not shown). As shown in Fig. 4C, the absorbances of L9Hel 13-5, Hel 13-5R, Hel 13-5Nle, and E3Hel 13-5 decreased drastically within 1 h and then reached a plateau at the peptide concentration of 20 µm (lipid/peptide = 5:1). This suggests that the size of vesicles became smaller than that of liposomes in the absence of peptides. Little change or a slight increase in turbidity, on the other hand, was observed for other peptides, suggesting a weaker or no interaction of the peptides with neutral liposomes. For Hel 13-5Nle, “immature” fibril-like structures formed (Fig. 4D), which were about 0.5–1 µm in length and 40 nm in diameter, much shorter than the structure formed by Hel 13-5. Interestingly, E3Hel 13-5 also created short fibril structures of about 300 nm in length and 50 nm in diameter, similar to Hel 13-5Nle (Fig. 4E). Both peptides created a mixture of α-helix and β-structures, indicating that the shape of the fibril may also depend on their secondary structure. No fibril structure was observed for the other peptides. Taken together, our results indicate that the chain length and the hydrophobic Leu residues of Hel 13-5 are critical to nanotubule formation, but the charged Lys residues in the hydrophilic region are replaceable by Arg or Glu residues. Experiments differing from the above only in the replacement of the egg PC liposomes with Golgi-specific phospholipid liposomes demonstrate similar trends (data not shown). We previously showed that Hel 13-5 adopts an α-helix structure when forming fibrils with egg-PC liposomes after 24 h incubation (6Kitamura A. Kiyota T. Tomohiro M. Umeda A. Lee S. Inoue T. Sugihara G. Biophys. J. 1999; 76: 1457-1468Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). The structure of Hel 13-5 remained α-helical as it formed fibrils with mixed liposome systems such as PC/PE (1:1), PC/PE/SM (5:3:2), PC/PE/Ch (5:3:2), and PC/PG, indicating that the fiber structure does not result from a conformational change of the peptide itself to β-structure. In our systems, the formation of nanotubules depends on peptide properties, the lipid composition, and lipid/peptide ratio. This is also seen in nature, with generation of lipid nanodomains in intracellular organelles, and with the structural changes in membranes triggered by relevant protein/lipid components. For example, the characteristic features obtained by using SM liposomes (Fig.2C) and Ch-contained liposomes (Fig. 2E) might reflect the dynamic movement of specialized nanodomains, lipid rafts, which are enriched in sphingolipids and Ch, and have been implicated in several cellular functions (10Simons K. Ikonen E. Nature. 1997; 387: 569-572Crossref PubMed Scopus (8048) Google Scholar). It has been shown that the pulmonary surfactant system consisting of several lipid and protein components is packed together in dense lamellar bodies that, in the alveoli, are converted to a lattice of tubular myelin bilayers (11Perez-Gil J. Keough K.M.W. Biochim. Biophys,. Acta. 1999; 1408: 203-217Crossref Scopus (195) Google Scholar). We found that when the liposomes were prepared from the composition of the lung surfactant lipids, Hel 13-5 converted them into a mixture of fiber and doughnut-type structures (Fig. 2F). This result suggests that peptides like Hel 13-5 could be used to assist in the transformation of lung surfactant between the lung surface film and the tubular myelin. The conversion of spherical liposomes into tubules has been demonstrated in a complex cell-free system composed of brain lipid extract and the proteins dynamin and amphyphisin, which have been proposed to participate in the endocytosis of synaptic vesicles. The addition of these proteins to a brain lipid extract transformed spherical protein-free liposomes into narrow tubules (12Sweitzer S.M. Hinshaw J.E. Cell. 1998; 93: 1021-1029Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (543) Google Scholar, 13Takei K. Slepnev V.L. Haucke V. De Camilli P. Nat. Cell Biol. 1999; 1: 33-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (510) Google Scholar). Although brain extract is not a simple phospholipid model system, the narrow tubules obtained from that system are very similar to ours. The most striking result of our studies is that the short de novo-designed peptide Hel 13-5 interacts with a Golgi-specific lipid mixture to create Golgi apparatus-like nanotubules. Both the nanotubule length (600 nm) and diameter (∼40–50 nm) were on the order of Golgi apparatus tubules. Furthermore, the ends of the nanotubules were pinched off to narrow diameters of ∼2–3 nm, giving the tubules a remarkable morphological resemblance to the nanotubules of the Golgi apparatus. It suggests that the membrane-bound proteins of such an organelle must at some level have properties embodied in Hel 13-5,e.g. the formation of hydrophobic helixes. In various morphological studies, it has been shown that such membrane tubules are generated from the Golgi complex and trans Golgi network, and serve as bridging between cisternal stacks (3Weidman P. Roth R. Heuser J. Cell. 1993; 75: 123-133Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar, 4Presley J.F. Smith C. Hirschberg K. Miller C. Cole N.B. Zaal K.J. Lippincott-Schwartz J. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1998; 9: 1617-1626Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). In addition to the precise role of these tubules in membrane trafficking events, the molecular mechanisms forming membrane tubules are not known. Our work provides a novel model system for the study of tubule formation in various intracellular events. Using this system, we have shown that lipid composition and peptide structure control nanotubule morphology. A thorough understanding of tubulation mechanisms will be critical to the creation of nanovesicular structures designed for example, to entrap and deliver drugs. Finally, although the question of precisely how nature engineers organellar membranes remains unknown, our approach provides a basic set of tools to begin addressing such questions.

Development of skeletal cartilage is characterized with coupling growth arrest and cell differentiation. Here, to understand the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors involved in the progression of chondrogenic differentiation, we examined changes in the expression levels of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor members using mouse ATDC5 prechondrocytes as a widely used in vitro model of cartilage differentiation. Up-regulation of p21 andp27 mRNA was observed following a decrease in growth rate of prechondrocytes, and both transcripts subsequently accumulated during chondrogenic differentiation; p15, p18, and p19 mRNA, in contrast, did not change during differentiation. Only the up-regulation of p21 mRNA during differentiation was prevented by the continuous treatment of early chondrogenic inhibitor, parathyroid hormone, indicating a close correlation between differentiation and p21 induction in ATDC5 cells. Therefore, to examine the role of p21 during chondrogenesis, we established stable cell lines overexpressing full-length p21 antisense RNA in ATDC5. The reduction of endogenous p21 in these cell lines caused inhibition of early chondrogenic differentiation in ATDC5, indicating thatp21 gene plays an important role in this process of the cells in vitro. Furthermore, the level of p21 protein and p21·CDK2 complexes transiently increased during differentiation, but not in undifferentiated cells, leading to a decrease in CDK2-associated kinase. However, differentiation-dependent expressed p21 protein was degraded by a proteasome-dependent pathway. Thus, the progression of chondrogenic differentiation requires down-regulation of CDK2-associated kinase with an increase in p21 protein and subsequent degradation of this protein by a proteasomal pathway. During chondrogenic differentiation, prechondrocytes differentiate to proliferating chondrocytes. As the rate of cell proliferation decreases, the chondrocytes begin to produce many extracellular matrix molecules, including type II and IX collagen, and aggrecan, and then finally cease to proliferate. The postmitotic chondrocytes terminally differentiate into hypertrophic chondrocytes, which produce type X collagen (19Howlett C.R. J. Anat. 1979; 128: 377-399PubMed Google Scholar, 20Stocum D.L. Davis R.M. Leger M. Conrad H.E. J. Embryol. Exp. Morphol. 1979; 54: 155-170PubMed Google Scholar). The progress of these differentiation processes requires crucial regulation by cytokines and hormones (21Hiraki Y. Inoue H. Hirai R. Kato Y. Suzuki F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 969: 91-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 22Hiraki Y. Inoue H. Kato Y. Fukuya M. Suzuki F. Mol. Cell Biochem. 1987; 76: 185-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). However, the intracellular mechanisms that regulate proliferation and differentiation programs are poorly understood. In this report, we examined the involvement of CKIs during chondrogenic differentiation, revealing that p21 gene expression was closely associated with early chondrogenic differentiation. To clarify whether the expression of p21 is required for differentiation, we established a cell line expressing antisense RNA of the p21 gene. It was shown that the cell line prevented the progression of chondrogenesis, indicating that p21 gene was directly involved in chondrogenic differentiation. Furthermore, down-regulation of CDK2-associated kinase during differentiation was accompanied by an increase in p21·CDK2 complexes in accordance with the amount of p21 protein, suggesting that p21 protein contributes to the inhibition of kinase activity during early chondrogenic differentiation. In addition, following a reduction in DNA synthesis, the expressed p21 protein is degraded via a proteasome-dependent pathway. Taken together, chondrogenesis may be promoted by p21 protein impairment of the CDK2-associated kinase and by post-translational modification of itself. Mouse ATDC5 prechondrocytes as a widely usedin vitro model of cartilage differentiation, were maintained in the absence of insulin, and were induced to chondrogenic cells by addition of differentiation medium containing insulin as described previously (23Atsumi T. Miwa Y. Kimata K. Ikawa Y. Cell Diff. Dev. 1990; 30: 109-116Crossref PubMed Scopus (339) Google Scholar, 24Shukunami C. Shigeno C. Atsumi T. Ishizeki K. Suzuki F. Hiraki Y. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 457-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (346) Google Scholar). Briefly, ATDC5 cells at 6.4 × 103cells/cm2 were spread into tissue culture plates and cultured in maintenance medium, a medium consisting of a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and Ham's F-12 medium containing 5% fetal bovine serum, 10 µg/ml human transferrin (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), and 3 × 10−8msodium selenite (Sigma), at 37 °C, 5% CO2 (24Shukunami C. Shigeno C. Atsumi T. Ishizeki K. Suzuki F. Hiraki Y. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 457-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (346) Google Scholar). To differentiate into chondrogenic cells, confluent cells were cultured long term period in differentiation medium, composed of maintenance medium containing 10 µg/ml bovine insulin (Roche Molecular Biochemicals). After 3 days, to inhibit chondrogenic differentiation, cells were continuously treated with 10−8mparathyroid hormone (PTH)-(1–34) (Peptide Institute, Inc.). Every fifth day, the degree of chondrogenesis was evaluated by alcian blue staining and examined by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis. Cells were cultured in maintenance medium or in differentiation medium containing 1 µCi/ml [methyl-3H]thymidine. After 4 h of incubation, they were fixed. Cells were then harvested, transferred onto a glass filter, and measured by liquid scintillation counter. Extraction and measurement of DNA contents were performed as described previously (25Schneider W.C. Methods Enzymol. 1957; 3: 680Crossref Scopus (1739) Google Scholar). Accumulation of sulfated glycosaminoglycan (GAG) by alcian blue staining was examined as reported elsewhere (26Asahina I. Sampath T.K. Hauschka P.V. Exp. Cell Res. 1996; 222: 38-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (227) Google Scholar). The degree of chondrogenic differentiation was evaluated by measuring the amount of extractable dye. The value was normalized against 1 µg of DNA from each culture. Anti-p21 polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology and Oncogene Research (Cambridge, MA). Anti-p27 monoclonal antibody was purchased from Transduction Laboratories. Anti-CDK2 polyclonal antibody was purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. Mouse p21 cDNA was provided by B. Vogelstein (Johns Hopkins Oncology Center, Baltimore, MD). pcDNA3 vector was purchased from Invitrogen (Invitrogen, CA). pcDNA3/ASp21 plasmid DNA was constructed as follows; the mouse p21 cDNA (both ends are EcoRI sites) was introduced in the antisense orientation, downstream (EcoRI site) of the CMV promoter of pcDNA3. This constructed pcDNA3/ASp21 was able to express complemental antisense RNA versus mouse p21 cDNA in mammalian cells. Total RNA was extracted from the long term cultured cells using the acid guanidinium isothiocyanate method (27Chomczynski P. Sacchi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (63230) Google Scholar). The RT reactions were performed as previously reported (28Negishi Y. Kudo A. Obinata A. Kawashima K. Hirano H. Yanai N. Obinata M. Endo H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 268: 450-455Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). The PCR conditions for type II collagen gene were 94 °C for 1 min, 56 °C for 2 min, and 72 °C for 3 min for 20–24 cycles (29Abe N. Yoshioka H. Inoue H. Ninomiya Y. Biochim. Biophys. To establish stable cell lines expressing antisense RNA versus mouse p21 gene, transfections with pcDNA3/ASp21 or pcDNA3 by lipofection methods 2K. Maruyama, manuscript in preparation. were performed. Liposome solutions (16 nmol of TMAG liposome (Daiichi Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd.), 256 µg of transferrin (Wako), 16 µg of salmon protamine sulfate (Sigma) were mixed with 8 µg of plasmid DNA (pcDNA3/ASp21 or pcDNA3), added to a 10-cm dish of 80% confluent culture ATDC5 cells in maintenance medium, incubated for 5 h, then washed with maintenance medium, and cultured for an additional 48 h. Following the additional incubation, cells were replated at 4.1 × 103 cells/cm2 and further cultured in medium containing 100 µg/ml G418 (Geneticin; Wako) for 10 days. The expression of antisense RNA derived from p21 cDNA in each clone was confirmed using specific primers to RT-PCR. The primers used were as follows: forward, 5′- TTGCAGAAGACCAATCTGCG (derived from mousep21 gene); reverse, 5′-CGAGCTCTAGCATTTAGGTG (partially derived from bovine growth hormone poly(A)+ sequence (bases 1008–1027) in pcDNA3). To examine stable integration of transfected DNA in each clone, genomic DNA was extracted from cell lines using DNAzol reagents (Life Technologies, Inc.). Using specific primers forβ-lactamasegene in pcDNA3 vector, and 100 ng of genomic DNA from each clone, PCR analysis was performed for 35 cycles as shown under “RT-PCR.” The primers used were as follows: forward, 5′-CCGTCGTGTAGATAACTACG; reverse, 5′-TCTTACGGATGGCATGACAG. Both primers were derived from β-lactamasegene in pcDNA3 vector. Cultured cells were washed with phosphate-buffered saline. Whole cell lysate was prepared with Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 120 mm NaCl, 0.5% Nonidet P-40, 1 mmNa3VO4, 10 µg/ml phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 45 µg/ml aprotinin). The protein concentration of cell lysates was determined by Bradford assay (Bio-Rad), and equal amounts of protein from each time point were used for Western blots, immunoprecipitation-Western blots, or kinase assay. Fifty micrograms of whole cell lysate was separated by 13.5% SDS-PAGE gels and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore). Blots were blocked overnight at 4 °C in phosphate-buffered saline containing 5% skim milk. After blocking, blots were incubated overnight in a 1:1000 dilution of primary antibody, followed by a 1:5000 dilution of anti-mouse or anti-rabbit IgG horseradish peroxidase-conjugated second antibody. Blots were developed with an ECL detection kit (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and exposed. Used blots were stripped according to the ECL protocol. This was followed by reprobing with a subsequent primary antibody. For immunoprecipitation, 500 µg of whole cell lysate was incubated with 10 µl of anti-CDK2 rabbit polyclonal antibody for 1.5 h at 4 °C. Protein G-Sepharose beads were added for 1.5 h, and complexes were washed four times with Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer. Immune complexes were run on 13.5% SDS-PAGE gels and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Millipore). Blots were managed according to Western blot methods as described under “Western Blots.” To measure CDK2-associated kinase activity, immunoprecipitates by anti-CDK2 polyclonal antibody were washed four times, resuspended in 7 µl of assay dilution buffer (20 mm MOPS (pH 7.2), 25 mm β-glycerol phosphate, 5 mm EGTA, 1 mm Na3VO4, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 7 µCi of [γ-32P]ATP). Seven microliters of inhibitor mixture (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.) and 1.5 µg of recombinant GST-RB (Santa Cruz) or histone H1 (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.) were then added to the immunoprecipitates, and subsequently the mixtures were incubated for 30 min at 30 °C. The reaction mixtures were analyzed on SDS-PAGE gels and exposed to x-ray film. The CDK2-associated kinase activities were measured by phosphorimaging analysis. Lactacystin and carbobenzoxy-l-leucyl-l-leucyl-l-leucinal (MG-132) were purchased from Calbiochem (San Diego, CA).trans-Epoxysuccinyl-l-leucylamido(4-guanidino)-butane (E64) was purchased from Sigma Japan. Cells were treated for 24 h with lactacystin (3 µm final), MG132 (3 µmfinal), or E64 (10 µm final). All compounds were dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), which did not exceed 1% of the assay medium concentration. First, to examine the relationship between cell growth and differentiation in ATDC5 cells, undifferentiated ATDC5 cells were cultured in maintenance medium until confluent (culture day 0 as shown in Fig.1) and were then further cultivated in maintenance or differentiation medium. [3H]Thymidine incorporation of induced and uninduced ATDC5 cells were compared (Fig.1 A). At day 1, thymidine incorporation increased under differentiation medium, and then decreased by day 13, where DNA synthesis reached a low and was maintained for 2 weeks. On the other hand, DNA synthesis of uninduced cells directly decreased. Therefore, the temporal elevation and subsequent decrease of DNA synthesis may be necessary to promote chondrogenic differentiation or to maintain differentiated chondrocytes. Indeed, the decrease of thymidine incorporation by day 8 in differentiation medium accompanied the increase in expression of type II collagengene as a gene marker of early chondrogenic differentiation (Fig. 1 B). Around day 12, cell growth completely ceased, and expression oftype X collagengene as a gene marker of late chondrogenic differentiation, was observed (Fig. 1 B). It has been reported that cell cycle progression is controlled by cyclin·CDK protein kinase where phosphorylating activity can be modulated by functionally and structurally distinct CKIs (1Sherr C.J. Roberts J.M. Genes Dev. 1995; 9: 1149-1163Crossref PubMed Scopus (3221) Google Scholar). To identify the CKIs involved in the progression of chondrogenic differentiation, we compared changes in CKI gene expression levels in ATDC5 prechondrocytes cultured in maintenance and differentiation medium, by RT-PCR analysis using specific primers.p15, p18, and p19 mRNA showed no remarkable change after chondrogenic induction (Fig. 1 B). Expression of p16 gene was not observed by RT-PCR analysis (data not shown). An increase in p21 and p27mRNA was observed at day 5, and both transcripts subsequently accumulated during chondrogenic differentiation (Fig. 1 B). The onset of the increase coincided with the abrupt decrease in the growth rate of prechondrocytes (Fig. 1 A). Expression ofp21 and p27 genes was seen prior to the up-regulation of gene marker, type II collagen(8–12 days), in early chondrogenic differentiation (Fig. 1 B). In contrast, expression of p21 and p27 genes changed little in ATDC5 prechondrocytes cultured for a long period in maintenance medium, and no expression of chondrogenic gene markers was observed. To examine whether the up-regulation of CKIgenes was associated with the progress of chondrogenic differentiation, we investigated the effect of PTH, which inhibits the progression of early chondrogenesis (24Shukunami C. Shigeno C. Atsumi T. Ishizeki K. Suzuki F. Hiraki Y. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 457-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (346) Google Scholar, 33Shukunami C. Ohta Y. Sakuda M. Hiraki Y. Exp. Cell Res. 1998; 241: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar), upon the up-regulation of these genes during differentiation. Fig.2A shows PTH completely inhibited synthesis of glycosaminoglycan, a marker of chondrogenic differentiation, as estimated by alcian blue staining. In addition totype II collagenmRNA, the increase of p21mRNA, detected in days 8, 13, and 18, was prevented by continuous treatment with PTH. Unlike p21 gene, expression ofp15, p18, p19, and p27mRNA changed little after chondrogenic inhibition (Fig.2 B). These results suggest that the expression ofp21 gene is closely associated with chondrogenic differentiation. To clarify whether the expression of p21 is required for progression of chondrogenic differentiation in ATDC5 cells, we established a cell line expressing antisense RNA of thep21 gene. An expression vector (pcDNA3/ASp21) was constructed, and was transfected into mouse ATDC5 cells by lipofection as shown under “Materials and Methods.” Genomic-PCR analysis showed that established cell lines (empty clones 1 and 2 or ASp21 clones 1 and 2) contained the pcDNA3/ASp21 expression vector or the pcDNA3 vector as amplicons derived from β-lactamasegene were detected (Fig. 3A). Semiquantitative RT-PCR analysis showed that p21 antisense RNA repressed the up-regulation of p21 mRNA during chondrogenic differentiation, and resulted in inhibited progression of early differentiation in chondrocytes because the increase oftype II collagengene expression and the synthesis of GAG during chondrogenesis were repressed (Fig. 3, B andC). These results indicate that endogenousp21 gene expression is required for the progression of early chondrocyte differentiation. The CIP/KIP family, including p21, controls various cell growth by inhibiting CDK2-associated kinase (1Sherr C.J. Roberts J.M. Genes Dev. 1995; 9: 1149-1163Crossref PubMed Scopus (3221) Google Scholar). Therefore, to understand the mechanism by which p21 regulates the differentiation, protein analysis was performed. Similar top21 mRNA, the amount of protein increased up to day 9 after chondrogenic induction, and thereafter the amount of expressed protein immediately decreased (Fig.4A). Increase of p21 protein, however, was not observed when ATDC5 cells were cultured in maintenance medium, whereas protein levels of CDK2, which is a target of p21 and/or p27 protein, changed little during long term culture in maintenance or differentiation medium. By immunoprecipitation using anti-CDK2 polyclonal antibody, we also assessed whether CDK2·p21 protein complexes were formed during the differentiation process (Fig. 4 B). These complexes increased up to day 9 and then decreased abruptly. The formation of the complexes may depend upon the amount of p21 protein, because this change coincided with that of p21 protein by Western blot analysis. Furthermore, to confirm whether CDK2-associated kinase activities were regulated by p21 protein during chondrogenic differentiation, we performed a CDK2-associated kinase assay using recombinant RB or H1 protein as a substrate for CDK2. The kinase activities of CDK2 protein decreased up to day 13 of culture (Fig. 4 C). This down-regulation of the kinase correlated with a reduction in DNA synthesis during differentiation as shown in Fig. 1. Unlike the p21 protein, p27 protein and CDK2·p27 complexes accumulated following a gradual increase up to culture days 9–13 in differentiation medium, but not in maintenance medium (Fig. 4, A andB). To further examine whether p21 protein is repressed by p21antisense RNA expression under differentiation medium, Western blot analysis was performed. Similar to the inhibition of endogenousp21 mRNA expression as shown in Fig. 3, protein production in ASp21 clone was repressed throughout long term culture in differentiation medium (Fig.5A). By immunoprecipitation using anti-CDK2 polyclonal antibody, we also assessed whether CDK2·p21 protein complexes were formed during long term culture in differentiation medium (Fig. 5 B). CDK2·p21 complexes were formed at very low level dependent on the amount of p21 protein. Furthermore, to confirm whether CDK2-associated kinase activities were affected by the repression of p21 protein in ASp21 clone under differentiation medium, we performed a CDK2-associated kinase assay as shown in Fig. 5 C. The kinase activities of CDK2 protein in ASp21 clone decreased up to day 3 of culture (Fig. 5 C). However, 3 days later, the kinase activities of CDK2 were maintained throughout long term culture (Fig. 5 C), whereas in empty clone, the kinase activities of CDK2 protein were completely inhibited at day 13 of culture. Unlike the p21 protein, p27 protein and CDK2·p27 complexes accumulated in differentiation medium. The protein level, however, changed little during long term culture. Post-transcribed p21 mRNA accumulated during chondrogenic differentiation, but its protein level transiently increased, suggesting possible post-translational modification of this protein. p21 protein is a substrate for proteasome-dependent degradation (34Blagosklonny M.V. Treatment with proteasome inhibitors did not lead to an increase in expression of p21 and p27 mRNA (Fig. 6 B). These results suggest that a specific proteasome-mediated pathway contributes to decreased expression of p21 protein during chondrogenesis. First, to understand the CKIs associated with the progression of chondrogenic differentiation, here, we examined changes in the expression levels of CKI members using mouse ATDC5 prechondrocytes. After induction of differentiation, the growth of prechondrocytes decreased and, at the same time, the expression of p21 andp27 mRNA increased. The expression of p21 andp27 mRNA preceded the up-regulation of early-chondrogenic marker, type II collagengene. To confirm whether the up-regulation of both p21 and p27genes was associated with the progression of chondrogenic differentiation, we investigated the effect of PTH, which inhibits the progression of early chondrogenesis (24Shukunami C. Shigeno C. Atsumi T. Ishizeki K. Suzuki F. Hiraki Y. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 133: 457-468Crossref PubMed Scopus (346) Google Scholar, 33Shukunami C. Ohta Y. Sakuda M. Hiraki Y. Exp. Cell Res. 1998; 241: 1-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). PTH caused a decrease inp21 but not p27 gene expression elevated by the differentiation condition. It thus indicated a close correlation between differentiation and p21 induction. To clarify whether the expression of p21 is required for progression of chondrogenic differentiation in ATDC5 cells, we established stable cell lines, which constitutively overexpressed full-length p21 antisense RNA in ATDC5. The established cell lines showed that abrogation of endogenous p21 gene in ATDC5 prevented the progression of chondrogenesis, as seen by repressed type II collagenexpression and GAG synthesis during chondrogenesis. These results indicate that the expression of p21 gene is required for the progression of chondrogenesis in ATDC5 cells. To understand the mechanism by which p21 is involved in chondrogenic differentiation, we further performed protein analysis in relation to p21 protein. From the immunoprecipitation analysis using anti-CDK2 polyclonal antibody, we found that CDK2·p21 complexes increase by day 9 and that the amount of p21 protein increases and subsequently decreases during chondrogenic differentiation. Moreover, by CDK2-associated kinase assay, we found that the kinase activities of CDK2 protein greatly diminished up to culture day 13. The down-regulation of CDK2-associated kinase activities correlated with the reduction of DNA synthesis during chondrogenic differentiation. These results demonstrated that p21 forms a complex with CDK2 and contributes to the reduction of CDK2-associated kinase activity, resulting in the reduction of the growth rate of prechondrocytes before the expression of chondrogenic differentiation markers. In addition, p21 protein expression at early stages of differentiation was very high, but its expression during long term culture in maintenance condition was still low, suggesting that p21 protein induction is specific in manner and important for the early stage of the differentiation process. These notions were also supported by protein analysis using ASp21 clone, because induction of p21 protein was completely inhibited and the CDK2-associated kinase activity after 3 days of culture in differentiation medium was maintained, leading to inhibited progression of chondrogenesis. On the other hand, the amount of p27 is consistent with that of CDK2·p27 complexes, gradually increasing up to cultured days 9–13 of the differentiation process. This suggests that p27 protein also contributes to the impaired kinase activities during chondrogenesis. In contrast to the transient increase of p21 protein, the stable accumulation of p27 protein following the reduction of DNA synthesis suggests that p27 protein may contribute to growth arrest and differentiation. If so, how is the p27 protein engaged in chondrogenesis? It is possible that (a) p27 protein may co-operate with p21 in growth control in early stages of chondrogenesis, or (b) p27 protein may contribute to maintain permanent growth arrest over the later stages of differentiation because of reduced p21 protein levels at that time. The former may be unlikely because an early chondrogenic inhibitor did not inhibit p27 mRNA expression. Therefore, after growth arrest by p21 protein in early stages of differentiation, p27 protein may maintain growth arrest and may not allow re-proliferation through permanent inhibition of CDK2-associated kinase over the later stages of differentiation, leading to the progression of chondrogenesis. This notion may be supported by reports that p27 protein accumulates in the quiescent state of terminally differentiated cells, which showed an impaired CDK-associated kinase (14Liu M. Lee M.H. In addition, p21 is decreased by a proteasomal pathway in terminal differentiated keratinocytes, and forced expression of p21 in these cells inhibited terminal differentiation (45Di Cunto F. Topley G. Calautti E. Hsiao J. Ong L. Seth P.K. Dotto G.P. Science. 1998; 280: 1069-1072Crossref PubMed Scopus (254) Google Scholar). Thus, the degradation of p21 protein by proteasome in early chondrogenic differentiation may be required to permit progression toward the later stages of differentiation. It is likely that p21 plays important roles in chondrogenic differentiation; however, there is a discrepancy since mice lacking p21 appear to develop normally (46Deng C. Zhang P. Harper J.W. Elledge S.J. Leder P. Cell. 1995; 82: 675-684Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1949) Google Scholar). However, there is a marked tendency to use multiple pathways for important processes in nature, a redundancy that may confuse simple interpretations of a null-mutation analysis (47Weintraub H. Cell. 1993; 75: 1241-1244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (931) Google Scholar). Therefore, in p21 knock-out mice, cell-cell interactions or other unknown factor(s) derived from other tissue may provide compensating processes for the normal development of cartilage even with the lack of p21 action. Our results suggest that the increase of p21 protein and the resulting depression of CDK2-associated kinase are essential for early stages of chondrogenesis and the degradation of p21 protein by a proteasome pathway in the later stages of differentiation is also prerequisite for the differentiation of chondrocytes. mRNA translation in eukaryotic cells involves a set of proteins termed translation initiation factors (eIFs), several of which are involved in the binding of ribosomes to mRNA. These include eIF4G, a modular scaffolding protein, and eIF4A, an RNA helicase, of which two closely related forms are known in mammals, eIF4AI and eIF4AII. In mammals, eIF4G possesses two independent sites for binding eIF4A, whereas in other eukaryotes (e.g. yeast) only one site appears to be present, thus raising the issue of the stoichiometry of eIF4G·eIF4A complexes in different eukaryotes. We show that in human embryonic kidney cells eIF4G is associated with eIF4AI or eIF4AII but not with both simultaneously, suggesting a stoichiometry of 1:1 rather than 1:2. To confirm this, eIF4AI or eIF4AII was expressed in a tagged form in these cells, and complexes with eIF4G were again isolated. Complexes containing tagged eIF4AI or eIF4AIIcontained no endogenous eIF4A, supporting the notion that eIF4G binds only one molecule of eIF4A. Each binding site in eIF4G can bind either eIF4AI or eIF4AII. The data imply that the second binding site in mammalian eIF4A does not bind an additional eIF4A molecule and that initiation factor complexes in different eukaryotes contain one eIF4A per eIF4G. mRNA translation in eukaryotic cells involves a set of proteins termed translation initiation factors (eIFs), several of which are involved in the binding of ribosomes to mRNA. Ni-NTA, nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid polymerase chain reaction polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis Translation of mRNA in mammalian cells involves a set of proteins termed “translation factors.” A number of the proteins are involved in the initiation phase of translation, the main control point in this process, and are accordingly termed “initiation factors” (eIFs).1 Several of the eIFs play a role in the recruitment of mRNAs to ribosomes and in the events leading to the recognition of the initiation codon. One such protein is eIF4A, an ATP-dependent RNA helicase of the “DEAD-box” family (1Gingras A.-C. Raught B. Sonenberg N. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1999; 68: 913-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (1761) Google Scholar, 2de la Cruz J. Kressler D. Linder P. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2000; 24: 192-198Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (433) Google Scholar). It is thought to act to remove regions of secondary structure within the 5′-untranslated region of the mRNA to facilitate ribosome binding and scanning (1Gingras A.-C. Raught B. Sonenberg N. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1999; 68: 913-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (1761) Google Scholar, 3Svitkin Y.V. Pause A. Haghighat A. Pyronnet S. Witherell G. Belsham G.J. Sonenberg N. RNA (N. Y.). 2001; 7: 382-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar). As revealed by the use of dominant negative mutants (4Pause A. Methot N. Svitkin Y. Merrick W.C. Sonenberg N. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 1205-1215Crossref PubMed Scopus (327) Google Scholar), eIF4A appears to be essential for cap-dependent and also for cap-independent initiation directed by picornavirus internal ribosome entry sites. eIF4A interacts with a scaffold protein, eIF4G, to form complexes that also contain the cap-binding protein eIF4E, which binds the cap structure (m7GpppN … ) at the 5′-end of the mRNA (for reviews see Refs. 1Gingras A.-C. Raught B. Sonenberg N. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1999; 68: 913-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (1761) Google Scholar and 5Pain V.M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 236: 747-771Crossref PubMed Scopus (637) Google Scholar)). Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 1134-1144Crossref PubMed Scopus (498) Google Scholar). Three related proteins have been designated as distinct forms of eIF4A. eIF4AI and eIF4AII are closely related and are both known to be cytoplasmic and to interact with eIF4G (7Conroy S.C. Dever T.E. Owens C.L. Merrick W.C. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1990; 282: 363-371Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar).
